Hankey, G.C.B.......................____ laa^estyHi novernmenTT)""^secret cabinet 7 (25).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet,held at 10, Downing Street, S.W.1, onWEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1925, at 11-30 a.m.house of lordsJar memorial.proposedRemoval of; Clue onVictoria1 sStatue.1. The Lord President of the Counoil gave theCabinet an account of . the circumstances leading upto the decision of a majority of the Members of theHouse of Lords that Queen Victoria's statue should beremoved from the Princes' Chamber to make room for theHouse of Lords War Memorial * as well as of the contro-versy which had subsequently arisen in regard to thisdecision. Lord Curzon stated that he himself had actedthroughout under the directions and with the authorityof the House of Lords, and that unless that decision were reversed he had no right to follow any other course.If it were decided to reverse it, the only means bywhich this could be done, otherwise than by a freshvote of the House of Lords, would be an expression of a desire on the part of the Sovereign that, in the absenceof complete unanimity on the matter, It would be undesirable to remove the statue of Queen Victoria.On the other hand, the opposite view was expressed,that,if It were desired to challenge the decision already reached, this should be done by a formal motion and vote in the House of Lords.The Cabinet agreed -'-That the matter should be left in thehands of the Leader of the House of Lords. Ma j9 sty*s Goverryieriw)"'-gBOEEI-OABINET 7 (25).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet,held at 10, Downing Street, S.W.1, onWEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1S25, at 11-30 a.m.HOUSE OF LORDSjfAR MEMORIAL.proposedpemoval ofIfictoria' sStatue.1. The Lord President of the Counoil gave theCabinet an account of . the circumstances leading upto the decision of a majority of the Members of theHouse of Lords that Queen Victoria's statue should beremoved from the Princes' Chamber to make room for theHouse of Lords War Memorialj as well as of the contro-versy which had subsequently arisen in regard to thisdecision. Lord Curzon stated that he himself had actedthroughout under the directions and with the authorityof the House of Lords, and that unless that decision were reversed he had no right to follow any other course.If It were decided to reverse it, the only means bywhich this could be done, otherwise than by a freshvote of the House of Lords, would be an expression of a desire on the part of the Sovereign that, in the absenceof complete unanimity on the matter, It would be undesirable to remove the statue of Queen Victoria.On the other hand, the opposite view was expressed,that jit it were desired to challenge the decision already reached, this should be done by a formal motion and vote in the House of Lords.The Cabinet agreed That the matter should be left in thehands of the Leader of the House of Lords. After consideration of a Memorandum bytho Postmaster General, (C.P, 29(25)), covering the draft Wireless Telegraphy and Visual SignallingBill, the object of which is to make permanent and to extend the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1904,together \:;ith the recommendations of the Committeeox Home Affairs thereon, (H.A.C 2nd Cons.(25),para.l), the.Cabinet agreed;-Subject to the redrafting of the- Wireless Telegraphy Bill as aconsolidating and amending measure,to authorise the introduction of theredrafted Bill in the House ofCommons as early as possible in theforthcoming Parliamentary Session. After consideration of a Memorandum by theIclSlTlES[jjl, Financial Secretary to the Treasury covering theWevious draft Trade Facilities Bill 1985, (CP. 41(25)),Inference:hairnet 27 together with the recommendations of the Committee(24), Con-conclusion 1(e).) of Home Affairs thereon, (H.A.C. 2nd Cons. (25) ,para.2), the Cabinet agreed:-(a) To authorise the increase of thelimit ( 65 million) laid down inthe Trade Facilities Act, 1924,to 70 million.(b) To approve the Trade Facilities Bill,1925, in the form of the draft annexed to CP. 41(25) subject to the additionof a clause to give effect to (a) above and to authorise the Tabling ox thenecessary Financial Resolution as soonas possible after the reassembly ofParliament *(c)ThatlaidAct jtionabovewhen the/increase of the limitdown in the Trade Facilities1924, was brought to the atten-of the House of Commons, itshould be stated that the proposed increase was as large as the Govem-ment, having regard to previous experience, expected to be able to utilise, and that it was undesirable to strain the national credit by increasing the guarantee beyond whatwas deemed necessary; but it shouldbe made clear that if the increaseof 5,000,000 should prove insufficientin practice, the Government would not hesitate to ask Parliament for an addition thereto. ! $SHOE ANTbpIBGgSHATlOHAI,SlOHS)p.Iviouslerence:meet 17), Con-bion 9. )4. After consideration of a Memorandum by thePresident of the Board of Trade, (CP. 6(25)), covering the Merchant Shipping (International Labout Conventions)Bill, the object of which is to give effect to threeInternational Conventions for the benefit of merchant seamen adopted by the International Labour Organisationof the League of Hat!Oils in 1920 and 1921, togetherwith the "recommendations of the Committee of HomeAffairs thereon, (H.A.C 2nd Cons.(25), para.3), theCabinet agreed:-To authorise the introduction in thoHouse of Lords as early .as possiblein the forthcoming parliamentary session of the Merchant Shipping(International Labour Conventions)Bill in the-form of the draft annexed to CP. 6(25). ROHAN 3?5.After consideration of a Memoran dam,IGN SHIPS) (CP. 33(25)), by'the President of the Board ofTrado covering the draft Merchant Shipping (foreign ships) Bill 1925, the main object of which is toenable Great Britain to make reciprocal agreements with Foreign Governments on the subject of wireless telegraphy on ships, together with the recomraenda-tions of the Committee of Home Affairs thereon,(how.Cc 2nd Cons.(25), para.4), the cabinet agreed: -To authorise the introduction inthe House of Lords as early; as possibleIn the forthcoming Parliamentary Sessionof the Merchant Shipping (Foreign Ships)Bill 1925, in the form of the draft annexed to CP. 33(25).1925. ptB formerIwSEY alleksDisabilitiesltA bill.6. After consideration'of Memoranda,(CP, 9(25) and CP. 11(85)), by the Presidentof the Board of Trade, the latter covering thedraft Former Enemy Aliems (Disabilities Removal)Bill, which has been prepared to give effect tothe undertaking embodied in the Anglo-German Treatyof Commerce that legislation will be enacted toremove the existing liabilities affecting Germancitizens and German Companies which do not extend toAliens and Alien Companies in general, together withthe recommendations of the Committee of Home affairs thereon, (E.A.C End Cons.(25), para.5), the cabinet agreed: -To authorise the introduction as soonas possible in the forthcoming parliamentary session of the Former Enemy Aliens(disabilities Removal) Bill in the formof the draft annexed to CP. 11(25). After consideration of a Memorandum by theIlome Secretary, (CP. 31(25)), covering the draft ofthe Borough Councillors (Alteration of Number) Bill,the object of which is to enable the number ofBorough Councillors to be altered by en Order-inrsCouncil in the case of a Municipal Borough and bythe Order of the Secretary of State in the case ofa Metropolitan Borough, together x^ith the recommenda-tions of the Committee of Home Affairs thereon,(H.A.C. 2nd Cons.(25), para.6, the Cabinet agreed:-To authorise the introduction assoon as possible in the forthcomingParliamentary Session of the borough Councillors (Alteration of number) Bill in the form of thedraft annexed to CP. 31(25). After consideration of a Memorandum bythe Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries, (CP.21(25)),Covering the draft Agricultural Returns Bill, the objectOf wb. ich is to make compulsory the collection of annual agricultural returns, together with therecommendations of the Committee of Home affairs thereon, (H.A.C 2nd Cons.(25), para.7), the cabinet agreed: -To authorise the introduction inthe House of Commons as soon aspossible in the forthcoming Sessionof the Agricultural Returns Bill inthe form of the draft annexed to cp. 21(25). llC HEALTHgypLML)Iviousllerence:Itinet 47I), Con-psion 17.)9. After consideration of a Memorandum bythe Secretary for Scotland, (CP, 27(25)), covering the draft Public Health (Scotland) Amendment bill which is a Bill to amend the Public Health (Scotland)Act 1897 so as to empower local authorities toprovide insulin treatment to persons suffering fromdiabetes who need assistance in obtaining the drug,together with the recommendations of the Committee^Home Affairs, (EoA.G. 2nd Consc(25), para.8), theCabinet agreed:--To authorise the introduction as early as possible in the forthcomingParliamentary Session of the PublicHealth (Scotland) Amendment Bill inthe form of the draft annexed to cp. 27(25). 10.Aft or consideration of a Memorandum "by theSecretary for Scotland, covering the draft Poor LawEmergency Provisions continuance (Scotland) Bill(Paper CP.-28 (25)), and the recommendation Of theCommittee of Home Affairs thereon (H.A.C 3rd -Cons. (25)Para.l), the Cabinet agreed To authorise the introduction in theHouse of Commons as soon as possiblein the forthcoming parliamentary session, of the Poor Law emergency provisions Continuance (Scotland)Bill in the form of the draft annexed to CP.-26 (25). rpHS IMPERIALInstituteill.(previous reference erence:Cabinet 4(25) , Oon-elusion 3(c).)11. (25) Para.6),the Cabinet agreed To authorise the introduction in theHouse of Commons as early as possiblein the forthcoming parliamentary session of the Summary Jurisdiction(separation and Maintenance) Billin the form of a draft annexed to cp--63 (25), subject to the omission of the word "voluntarily"In Clause 1 (4J and to any drafting alterations which may be foundnece ssary. 16. After consideration of a Memorandum by the HomeSecretary (Paper CP. -64 (25)), coyering a draftGuardiahhhip of Infants Bill, and of the recommendationof the Committee of Home Affairs thereon (H.A.C 3rd*Cons. (25), Para. 7), the Cabinet agreed To authorise the introduction in theHouse of Commons as early as possiblein the forthcoming parliamentary session of the Guardianship of InfantsBill in the form of a draft annexed to cp.-64 (25), Subject to the omission of the word' "voluntarily" in Clause3 (3). 17. After considernation of a Note "by the Seoretarieof the Committee of Home Affairs (Paper cp-60 (25))covering Mr Blundell1^ Bill on the subject of - "Roman Catholic Relief? of a Memorandum by the HomeSeoretary (Paper CP.-70 (25)), and of the recommenda-tion of the Committee of Home Affairs thereon (H.A.C.3rd. Cons. (25) ? Para, s) , the Cabinet, agreed 1That in view of its controversialcharacter the Roman Catholic ReliefBill should not be adopted by theGovernment. INDEMNITY I8- After consideration of Conclusion 10 of HomeMr^HBESTON. Affairs Committee 3 (25), the Cabinet agreed To authorise the introduction in theHouse of Commons as soon as possiblein the forthcoming parliamentary session of an Indemnity Bill to relieve Mr Preston from the oonse-quences of voting, as Member forWalsall, while under statutorydisability to sit and vote. AOAUOIBS.proposed addi-ional Judgen the Probatepivision.fpreviousHeferenco:Cabinet 60(24), Con-conclusion 4.)19. After consideration of a Kote by the lordChancellor urging the appointment of an additionalJudge in the Probate Division, (CP. 5(35)), theCab inet agreed:-That the provision enabling theappointment of the third Judgeshould be inserted in theAdministration of Justice Billabout to be introduced in theHouse of 2*ords. 20. The Seoretary of State for Foreign affairs gave the Cabinet an account of certain salient points which had arisen in the course of his farewell conversation with Mr Kellogg,the American Ambassador, who wasabout to take up the post vf Secretary of State atWashington. In regard to a very confidential coromanication he had received as to the attitude of PresidentCoolidge towards the Geneva Protocol, Mr austen chamberlain had told Mr Kellogg that he did not proposeto circulate it in the usual manner (C.I.D. Paper573-B). He had,'however, pointed &ut to Mr Kelloggthat if the American attitude was so adverse to the geneva Protocol, it might be very useful if some formof public announcement could bo made on the subject, r\\since such an announcement would obviously have agreat effect upon the nations which were now consider-ing their attitude towards the Protocol. Mr Kellogghad given a very favourable reception to this proposal.Mr Kellogg had also discussed the question of disarmament, and had suggested that, having regard tothe small size of the land forces of the United Statescf America as well as of Great Britain, he had feltthat it would not be useful for the United StatesGovernment to summon a Conference to consider thequestion of land armaments. Mr Chamberlain had thentold Mr Kellogg that M. Herriot had intimated that,in his view, Washington would not be a good centre inwhich to discuss land armaments, o^ing to its remotenesfrom the European questions with the solution of whichthis question was so closely connected. In reply toMr Kellogg's suggestion that a Conference on navallAmiftation of armaments might be summoned moreusefully, Mr Chamberlain had suggested that the American Government should put out "feelers" withother Governments as to their attitude twards theproposal. He had himself entered a caveat in regardto the obvious difficulties of rationing the oonstruc--m or ^-f nwiiaoTs nn t,"Ke same lines as capital ships 5"submarine question. In the course of a conversation which included a survey of the political situation allover the world, Mr Kellogg had expressed the view thatthe intentions of Japan were peaceful, and that althoughthe United States of America could not yield Inprinciple on the question of immigration, some meansmight perhaps bo found to save the face of Japan.saia that we should welcome a Conferenceand haa suggested that it might considersuoh questions as the"nt and the-21- -21-American Government should put out rfeelers" withother Governments as to their attitude twards theproposal. He had himself entered a caveat in regardto the obvious difficulties of rationing the oonstruc-tion of cruisers on.the same lines as capital ships?but hadsize of cruisers, the rate of replacement and thesubmarine question. In the course of a conversation which included a survey of the political situation allover the world, Mr Kellogg had expressed the view thatthe intentions of Japan were peaceful, and that althoughthe United States of America could not yield inprinciple on the question of immigration, some meansmight perhaps bo found to save the face of Japan. The Cabinet had before them Memoranda by theFirst Lord of the Admiralty (Papers CP, -38 (25) andC-P.-67 (25)) and the Chancellor of the Exchequer(Papers CP. -39 (25) and CP.-71 (25)), on the subjectof Naval Estimates.After listening to the opening statements of theFirst Lord of the Admiralty and Chancellor of theExchequer, the Cabinet entered on a general discussion on the subject, whioh was eventually adjourned untilthe following day.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,February 11,, 1925.
